message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest an asthma exacerbation, but the fact that his oxygen saturation is 92% on room air and his respiratory rate is 32/min indicate a severe exacerbation. Respiratory acidosis, caused by the retention of carbon dioxide due to inadequate ventilation, is a life-threatening complication of severe asthma exacerbation. PEFR >70% suggests mild to moderate exacerbation, dyspnea that limits daily activity suggests moderate to severe exacerbation, and symptoms lasting >3 days after starting treatment suggest inadequate response to treatment.

A PaCO2 greater than 45 mm Hg is considered severe respiratory acidosis and can lead to respiratory failure if left untreated. The other options describe the severity or duration of the patient’s symptoms but do not indicate a life-threatening condition.
